trans-unit.source: Azure Data Factory - Frequently Asked Questions
trans-unit.target: Azure Data Factory - Frequently Asked Questions

trans-unit.source: Frequently asked questions about Azure Data Factory.
trans-unit.target: Frequently asked questions about Azure Data Factory.

trans-unit.source: Data Factory is a cloud-based data integration service that orchestrates and automates the movement and transformation of data.
trans-unit.target: Data Factory is a cloud-based data integration service that orchestrates and automates the movement and transformation of data.

trans-unit.source: Just like a manufacturing factory that runs equipment to take raw materials and transform them into finished goods, Data Factory orchestrates existing services that collect raw data and transform it into ready-to-use information.
trans-unit.target: Just like a manufacturing factory that runs equipment to take raw materials and transform them into finished goods, Data Factory orchestrates existing services that collect raw data and transform it into ready-to-use information.

trans-unit.source: Data Factory works across on-premises and cloud data sources and SaaS to ingest, prepare, transform, analyze, and publish your data.
trans-unit.target: Data Factory works across on-premises and cloud data sources and SaaS to ingest, prepare, transform, analyze, and publish your data.

trans-unit.source: Use Data Factory to compose services into managed data flow pipelines to transform your data using services like <linkText>Azure HDInsight (Hadoop)</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Azure Batch</linkText><title></title> for your big data computing needs, and with <linkText>Azure Machine Learning</linkText><title></title> to operationalize your analytics solutions.
trans-unit.target: Use Data Factory to compose services into managed data flow pipelines to transform your data using services like <linkText>Azure HDInsight (Hadoop)</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Azure Batch</linkText><title></title> for your big data computing needs, and with <linkText>Azure Machine Learning</linkText><title></title> to operationalize your analytics solutions.

trans-unit.source: Go beyond just a tabular monitoring view, and use the rich visualizations of Data Factory to quickly display the lineage and dependencies between your data pipelines.
trans-unit.target: Go beyond just a tabular monitoring view, and use the rich visualizations of Data Factory to quickly display the lineage and dependencies between your data pipelines.

trans-unit.source: Monitor all of your data flow pipelines from a single unified view to easily pinpoint issues and setup monitoring alerts.
trans-unit.target: Monitor all of your data flow pipelines from a single unified view to easily pinpoint issues and setup monitoring alerts.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Overview & Key Concepts</linkText><title></title> for more details.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Overview & Key Concepts</linkText><title></title> for more details.

trans-unit.source: Azure Data Factory balances the agility of leveraging diverse data storage, processing and movement services across traditional relational storage alongside unstructured data, with the control and monitoring capabilities of a fully managed service.
trans-unit.target: Azure Data Factory balances the agility of leveraging diverse data storage, processing and movement services across traditional relational storage alongside unstructured data, with the control and monitoring capabilities of a fully managed service.

trans-unit.source: Data Developers: who are responsible for building integration services between Hadoop and other systems:
trans-unit.target: Data Developers: who are responsible for building integration services between Hadoop and other systems:

trans-unit.source: Must keep up and integrate with a continually changing and growing data landscape
trans-unit.target: Must keep up and integrate with a continually changing and growing data landscape

trans-unit.source: Must write custom code for information production, and it is expensive, hard to maintain, and not highly available or fault tolerant
trans-unit.target: Must write custom code for information production, and it is expensive, hard to maintain, and not highly available or fault tolerant

trans-unit.source: IT Professionals: who are looking to incorporate more diverse data within their IT infrastructure:
trans-unit.target: IT Professionals: who are looking to incorporate more diverse data within their IT infrastructure:

trans-unit.source: Required to look across all of an organization’s data to derive rich business insights
trans-unit.target: Required to look across all of an organization’s data to derive rich business insights

trans-unit.source: Must manage compute and storage resources to balance cost and scale across on-premises and cloud
trans-unit.target: Must manage compute and storage resources to balance cost and scale across on-premises and cloud

trans-unit.source: Must quickly add diverse sources and processing to address new business needs, while maintaining visibility across all compute and storage assets
trans-unit.target: Must quickly add diverse sources and processing to address new business needs, while maintaining visibility across all compute and storage assets

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Data Factory Pricing Details page[adf-pricing-details]</linkText><title></title> for the pricing details for the Azure Data Factory.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Data Factory Pricing Details page[adf-pricing-details]</linkText><title></title> for the pricing details for the Azure Data Factory.

trans-unit.source: For an overview of Azure Data Factory, see <linkText>Introduction to Azure Data Factory[adf-introduction]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For an overview of Azure Data Factory, see <linkText>Introduction to Azure Data Factory[adf-introduction]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: For a quick tutorial, see <linkText>Get started with Azure Data Factory[adfgetstarted]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For a quick tutorial, see <linkText>Get started with Azure Data Factory[adfgetstarted]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: For comprehensive documentation, see <linkText>Azure Data Factory documentation[adf-documentation-landingpage]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For comprehensive documentation, see <linkText>Azure Data Factory documentation[adf-documentation-landingpage]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Customers can get access to Data Factory through the <linkText>Azure Preview Portal[azure-preview-portal]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Customers can get access to Data Factory through the <linkText>Azure Preview Portal[azure-preview-portal]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Data Factory is available in US West and North Europe.
trans-unit.target: Data Factory is available in US West and North Europe.

trans-unit.source: The compute and storage services used by data factories can be in other regions.
trans-unit.target: The compute and storage services used by data factories can be in other regions.

trans-unit.source: See Azure Data Factory Limits section of the Azure Subscription and Service Limits, Quotas, and Constraints article.
trans-unit.target: See Azure Data Factory Limits section of the Azure Subscription and Service Limits, Quotas, and Constraints article.

trans-unit.source: You can author/create data factories using one of the following:
trans-unit.target: You can author/create data factories using one of the following:

trans-unit.source: Azure Preview Portal.
trans-unit.target: Azure Preview Portal.

trans-unit.source: The Data Factory blades in the Azure Preview Portal provide rich user interface for you to create data factories ad linked services.
trans-unit.target: The Data Factory blades in the Azure Preview Portal provide rich user interface for you to create data factories ad linked services.

trans-unit.source: The Data Factory Editor, which is also part of the portal, allows you to easily create linked services, tables, data sets, and pipelines by specifying JSON definitions for these artifacts.
trans-unit.target: The Data Factory Editor, which is also part of the portal, allows you to easily create linked services, tables, data sets, and pipelines by specifying JSON definitions for these artifacts.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Data Factory Editor[data-factory-editor]</linkText><title></title> for an overview of the editor and <linkText>Get started with Data Factory[datafactory-getstarted]</linkText><title></title> for an example of using the portal/editor to create and deploy a data factory.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Data Factory Editor[data-factory-editor]</linkText><title></title> for an overview of the editor and <linkText>Get started with Data Factory[datafactory-getstarted]</linkText><title></title> for an example of using the portal/editor to create and deploy a data factory.

trans-unit.source: Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: If you are a PowerShell user and prefer to use PowerShell instead of Portal UI, you can use Azure Data Factory cmdlets that are shipped as part of Azure PowerShell to create and deploy data factories.
trans-unit.target: If you are a PowerShell user and prefer to use PowerShell instead of Portal UI, you can use Azure Data Factory cmdlets that are shipped as part of Azure PowerShell to create and deploy data factories.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Create and monitor Azure Data Factory using Azure PowerShell[create-data-factory-using-powershell]</linkText><title></title> for a simple example and <linkText>Tutorial: Move and process log files using Data Factory[adf-tutorial]</linkText><title></title> for an advanced example of using PowerShell cmdles to create ad deploy a data factory.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Create and monitor Azure Data Factory using Azure PowerShell[create-data-factory-using-powershell]</linkText><title></title> for a simple example and <linkText>Tutorial: Move and process log files using Data Factory[adf-tutorial]</linkText><title></title> for an advanced example of using PowerShell cmdles to create ad deploy a data factory.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Data Factory Cmdlet Reference[adf-powershell-reference]</linkText><title></title> content on MSDN Library for a comprehensive documentation of Data Factory cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Data Factory Cmdlet Reference[adf-powershell-reference]</linkText><title></title> content on MSDN Library for a comprehensive documentation of Data Factory cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: You can also use Visual Studio to programmatically create, monitor, and manage data factories.
trans-unit.target: You can also use Visual Studio to programmatically create, monitor, and manage data factories.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Create, monitor, and manage Azure data factories using Data Factory .NET SDK</linkText><title></title> article for details.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Create, monitor, and manage Azure data factories using Data Factory .NET SDK</linkText><title></title> article for details.

trans-unit.source: .NET Class Library.
trans-unit.target: .NET Class Library.

trans-unit.source: You can programmatically create data factories by using Data Factory .NET SDK.
trans-unit.target: You can programmatically create data factories by using Data Factory .NET SDK.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Create, monitor, and manage data factories using .NET SDK[create-factory-using-dotnet-sdk]</linkText><title></title> for a walkthrough of creating a data factory using .NET SDK.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Create, monitor, and manage data factories using .NET SDK[create-factory-using-dotnet-sdk]</linkText><title></title> for a walkthrough of creating a data factory using .NET SDK.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Data Factory Class Library Reference[msdn-class-library-reference]</linkText><title></title> for a comprehensive documentation of Data Factory .NET SDK.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Data Factory Class Library Reference[msdn-class-library-reference]</linkText><title></title> for a comprehensive documentation of Data Factory .NET SDK.

trans-unit.source: REST API.
trans-unit.target: REST API.

trans-unit.source: You can also use the REST API exposed by the Azure Data Factory service to create and deploy data factories.
trans-unit.target: You can also use the REST API exposed by the Azure Data Factory service to create and deploy data factories.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Data Factory REST API Reference[msdn-rest-api-reference]</linkText><title></title> for a comprehensive documentation of Data Factory REST API.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Data Factory REST API Reference[msdn-rest-api-reference]</linkText><title></title> for a comprehensive documentation of Data Factory REST API.

trans-unit.source: No.
trans-unit.target: No.

trans-unit.source: Like other Azure resources, the name of an Azure data factory cannot be changed.
trans-unit.target: Like other Azure resources, the name of an Azure data factory cannot be changed.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Data Movement Activities</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Data Transformation Activities</linkText><title></title> articles for the supported data sources and activities.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Data Movement Activities</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Data Transformation Activities</linkText><title></title> articles for the supported data sources and activities.

trans-unit.source: The availability configuration setting in the output data table determines when the activity is run.
trans-unit.target: The availability configuration setting in the output data table determines when the activity is run.

trans-unit.source: The activity checks whether all the input data dependencies are satisfied (i.e., Ready state) before it starts running.
trans-unit.target: The activity checks whether all the input data dependencies are satisfied (i.e., Ready state) before it starts running.

trans-unit.source: Pipelines are supposed to bundle related activities.
trans-unit.target: Pipelines are supposed to bundle related activities.

trans-unit.source: Logically, you can keep the activities in one pipeline if the tables that connect them are not consumed by any other activity outside the pipeline.
trans-unit.target: Logically, you can keep the activities in one pipeline if the tables that connect them are not consumed by any other activity outside the pipeline.

trans-unit.source: This way, you would not need to chain pipeline active periods so that they align with each other.
trans-unit.target: This way, you would not need to chain pipeline active periods so that they align with each other.

trans-unit.source: Also, the data integrity in the tables internal to the pipeline will be better preserved when updating the pipeline.
trans-unit.target: Also, the data integrity in the tables internal to the pipeline will be better preserved when updating the pipeline.

trans-unit.source: Pipeline update essentially stops all the activities within the pipeline, removes them, and creates them again.
trans-unit.target: Pipeline update essentially stops all the activities within the pipeline, removes them, and creates them again.

trans-unit.source: From authoring perspective, it might also be easier to see the flow of data within the related activities in one JSON file for the pipeline.
trans-unit.target: From authoring perspective, it might also be easier to see the flow of data within the related activities in one JSON file for the pipeline.

trans-unit.source: See the Geographic Availability section in the following article: or <linkText>HDInsight Pricing Details[hdinsight-supported-regions]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: See the Geographic Availability section in the following article: or <linkText>HDInsight Pricing Details[hdinsight-supported-regions]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The on-demand HDInsight cluster is created in the same region where the storage you specified to be used with the cluster exists.
trans-unit.target: The on-demand HDInsight cluster is created in the same region where the storage you specified to be used with the cluster exists.

trans-unit.source: If you are using your own HDInsight Cluster (BYOC - Bring Your Own Cluster), see the following topics:
trans-unit.target: If you are using your own HDInsight Cluster (BYOC - Bring Your Own Cluster), see the following topics:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Using an HDInsight Cluster with Alternate Storage Accounts and Metastores[hdinsight-alternate-storage]</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Using an HDInsight Cluster with Alternate Storage Accounts and Metastores[hdinsight-alternate-storage]</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Use Additional Storage Accounts with HDInsight Hive[hdinsight-alternate-storage-2]</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Use Additional Storage Accounts with HDInsight Hive[hdinsight-alternate-storage-2]</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: If you are using an on-demand cluster that is created by the Data Factory service, you need to specify additional storage accounts for the HDInsight linked service so that the Data Factory service can register them on your behalf.
trans-unit.target: If you are using an on-demand cluster that is created by the Data Factory service, you need to specify additional storage accounts for the HDInsight linked service so that the Data Factory service can register them on your behalf.

trans-unit.source: In the JSON definition for the on-demand linked service, use additionalLinkedServiceNames property to specify alternate storage accounts as shown in the following JSON snippet:
trans-unit.target: In the JSON definition for the on-demand linked service, use additionalLinkedServiceNames property to specify alternate storage accounts as shown in the following JSON snippet:

trans-unit.source: In the example above, otherLinkedServiceName1 and otherLinkedServiceName2 represent linked services whose definitions contain credentials that the HDInsight cluster needs to access alternate storage accounts.
trans-unit.target: In the example above, otherLinkedServiceName1 and otherLinkedServiceName2 represent linked services whose definitions contain credentials that the HDInsight cluster needs to access alternate storage accounts.

trans-unit.source: The Stored Procedure Activity supports only Azure SQL Database at this time.
trans-unit.target: The Stored Procedure Activity supports only Azure SQL Database at this time.

trans-unit.source: You can rerun a slice in one of the following ways:
trans-unit.target: You can rerun a slice in one of the following ways:

trans-unit.source: Click Run in the command bar on the DATA SLICE blade for the slice in the portal.
trans-unit.target: Click Run in the command bar on the DATA SLICE blade for the slice in the portal.

trans-unit.source: Run Set-AzureDataFactorySliceStatus cmdlet with Status set to PendingExecution for the slice.
trans-unit.target: Run Set-AzureDataFactorySliceStatus cmdlet with Status set to PendingExecution for the slice.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Set-AzureDataFactorySliceStatus[set-azure-datafactory-slice-status]</linkText><title></title> for details about the cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Set-AzureDataFactorySliceStatus[set-azure-datafactory-slice-status]</linkText><title></title> for details about the cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Click Datasets tile on the DATA FACTORY blade for your data factory.
trans-unit.target: Click Datasets tile on the DATA FACTORY blade for your data factory.

trans-unit.source: Click the specific dataset on the Datasets blade.
trans-unit.target: Click the specific dataset on the Datasets blade.

trans-unit.source: Select the slice that you are interested in from the Recent slices list on the TABLE blade.
trans-unit.target: Select the slice that you are interested in from the Recent slices list on the TABLE blade.

trans-unit.source: Click the activity run from the Activity Runs list on the DATA SLICE blade.
trans-unit.target: Click the activity run from the Activity Runs list on the DATA SLICE blade.

trans-unit.source: Click Properties tile on the ACTIVITY RUN DETAILS blade.
trans-unit.target: Click Properties tile on the ACTIVITY RUN DETAILS blade.

trans-unit.source: You should see the DURATION field with a value.
trans-unit.target: You should see the DURATION field with a value.

trans-unit.source: This is the time taken to process the slice.
trans-unit.target: This is the time taken to process the slice.

trans-unit.source: If you need to stop the pipeline from executing, you can use <linkText>Suspend-AzureDataFactoryPipeline</linkText><title></title> cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: If you need to stop the pipeline from executing, you can use <linkText>Suspend-AzureDataFactoryPipeline</linkText><title></title> cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Currently, suspending the pipeline does not stop the slice executions that are in progress.
trans-unit.target: Currently, suspending the pipeline does not stop the slice executions that are in progress.

trans-unit.source: Once the in-progress executions finish, no extra slice is picked up.
trans-unit.target: Once the in-progress executions finish, no extra slice is picked up.

trans-unit.source: If you really want to stop all the executions immediately, the only way would be to delete the pipeline and create it again.
trans-unit.target: If you really want to stop all the executions immediately, the only way would be to delete the pipeline and create it again.

trans-unit.source: If you choose to delete the pipeline, you do NOT need to delete tables and linked services used by the pipeline.
trans-unit.target: If you choose to delete the pipeline, you do NOT need to delete tables and linked services used by the pipeline.

trans-unit.target: ./media/data-factory-faq/rerun-slice.png
